message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: 
```java
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.BufferedWriter;
import java.io.FileReader;
import java.io.FileWriter;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

public class fs {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("C:/Users/madhan kumar/Desktop/read.txt"));
            String line;
            BufferedWriter bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("out.txt"));
            
            while ((line = in.readLine()) != null) {
                StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(line, "|");
                String name = st.nextToken();
                String age = st.nextToken();
                String sex = st.nextToken();
                String field = st.nextToken();
                
                System.out.println("Name: " + name + " Age: " + age + " Sex: " + sex + " Field: " + field);
                bw.write("Name: " + name + " Age: " + age + " Sex: " + sex + " Field: " + field);
                bw.newLine();
            }
            
            in.close();
            bw.close();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            System.out.println(e);
        }
    }
}
```

<<<explanation>>>: 
To print all the lines from the text file, you can use the `StringTokenizer` class to split each line into separate tokens using the delimiter "|". Then, you can retrieve each token using the `nextToken()` method.

In the provided code, I have made the following changes:
1. Added import statements for `BufferedReader`, `BufferedWriter`, `FileReader`, `FileWriter`, and `StringTokenizer`.
2. Changed the class name to `fs` (should start with an uppercase letter).
3. Added a `main` method to execute the code.
4. Created a `BufferedReader` object to read from the input file.
5. Created a `BufferedWriter` object to write to the output file.
6. Added a `while` loop to read each line from the input file.
7. Inside the loop, created a `StringTokenizer` object to split the line into tokens.
8. Retrieved each token using the `nextToken()` method and assigned them to respective variables.
9. Printed the values of each variable using `System.out.println()`.
10. Wrote the values of each variable to the output file using `bw.write()` and `bw.newLine()`.
11. Closed the input and output streams.

Now, when you run the program, it will print all the lines from the input file and write them to the output file.
